Please Don’t Make Me Organize Any Drawers…

Published on January 9, 2025

Daily writing prompt
Where can you reduce clutter in your life?
View all responses

3 Things I’ve Done to Reduce “Clutter” in My Life

If there’s one thing I’ve learned, it’s that clutter comes in many forms, and not all of it is as simple as clearing a messy desk. Sure, physical clutter plays a role, but the real weight often comes from digital, emotional, and mental chaos that piles up until it feels like you’re carrying it all on your back. Over the past year, I’ve been intentional about cutting out the noise, and here are three changes that have made a big difference for me.

1. Streamlining My Work Tools

When it comes to work, I’m all about efficiency and simplicity. Over time, I found myself surrounded by too many tools. Multiple apps, overlapping platforms, and a tangled mess of software and back ends that just slowed me down and muddied my vision.

The solution? Consolidation. I pared down my tech stack to just a few essentials that do what I need without the extra fluff. Whether it’s switching to a single project management app or relying on one design tool instead of five, focusing on the essentials has cleared out the digital clutter and made my workflow smoother than ever. Bonus: it’s easier on the eyes and my hands (which have seen their fair share of repetitive strain lately).

Part of this also involved changing my design choice. I would normally say more more more, especially when building a website, but accepting a motto of less is more has been a huge eye opener for me.

2. Reevaluating Commitments

This was a tough one. The “clutter” I’m talking about here isn’t physical, it’s the mental kind that creeps in when you say “yes” too often. For a while, I felt stretched between too many projects, too many ideas, and way too many expectations.

The fix? I learned how to say “no” more often. And no, that doesn’t mean shutting down opportunities, it just means getting brutally honest about what aligns with my goals and what doesn’t. It’s amazing how much mental space opens up when you’re not juggling 15 different things at once.

3. Reframing My Digital Habits

I love tech, but let’s face it: digital clutter is sneaky. A cluttered inbox, 50 browser tabs, and notifications from apps you forgot you even had… it all adds up. The worst part is, it messes with your focus and makes you feel constantly “on.”

What I did was set boundaries. For starters, I turned off all non-essential notifications. I also started using a dedicated email time instead of obsessively checking throughout the day. And yeah, I’ll admit it: closing all those tabs and switching to Arc was like pulling weeds from my brain.

Reducing clutter, whether it’s physical, mental, or digital, has been less about what I’ve removed and more about what I’ve kept. The space I’ve gained lets me focus on what actually matters, like creating meaningful content, spending time with my family, and staying sane in a fast-paced world.

It’s not about perfection. My desk might still get messy, and I’m sure I’ll slip back into old habits occasionally. But for now, I can breathe a little easier, and that’s a win in my book.

How do you deal with clutter in your life? Let me know. I’m always open to new ideas (as long as they’re not about organizing drawers).
